Side shot of Opilio parietinus with the rounded body typical of most harvestman © Paul Richards.

Mitopus morio var morio showing a double-pinched 'waist' of saddle © Paul Richards.
The more or less straight-sided saddle of Odiellus spinosus © Paul Richards.

The saddle of Homalenotus quadridentatus is composed of dark spots © Paul Richards.
Female Opilio saxatilis showing a central longitudinal pale stripe up the saddle © Paul Richards.
Dorsal tubercles with swollen ends belonging to Mitostoma chrysomelas (left) and Nemastomella bacillifera (right) © Richard Burkmar.
The very consipicuous white tubercles on the body of a male Paroligolophus meadii © Paul Richards.
The exceptionally robust trident of a female Odiellus spinosus © Paul Richards.
The trident of Oligolophus hanseni is relatively inconspicuous to the naked eye (though it is usually very obvious under a hand lens).
These tubercles at the leading edge of the cepahlothorax in Opilio parietinus can't be described as a trident because there are no tubercles on the mid-line.
Homalenotus quadridentatus has a single large, forward projecting spine at the front of the cephalothorax.
Two UK harvestmen (e.g. this Trogulus tricarinatus) have a 'hood' projecting from the front of the cephalothorax which covers the mouthparts.
Many species of UK harvestman, e.g. this Nelima gothica don't have any type of projection at the front of the cephalothorax (though there might be some small tubercles around and about).

Examples of trident orientations. From left to right: near vertical (drawing is Paroligolophus agrestis); inclined forward (drawing is Lophopilio palpinalis); near horizontal (drawing is Odiellus spinosus) © Richard Burkmar.

Examples of trident middle member relative lengths. From left to right: equal (drawing is Odiellus spinosus); central slightly longer (drawing is Paroligolophus agrestis); central much longer (drawing is Lophopilio palpinalis) © Richard Burkmar.

A harvestman without an ocularium ( Anelasmocephalus cambridgei). Note that the head is raised in the region of the eyes here, but it is not a distinct ocularium.
